Phono-semantic matching  


Stronger than soft [alignment](alignment.html)  
Weaker than [permutation](permutation.html) and [reverse](reverse.html)  

[Wanderwords](Wanderwords.html) which are adopted phonetically but reinterpreted beyond [reanalysis](reanalysis.html) undergo so called Phono-semantic matching: e.g.  

WWW World Wide Web, which is wÃ n wÃ©i wÇng (ä¸‡ç»´ç½‘), which satisfies "www" and literally means â€œmyriad dimensional netâ€  
hacker has been borrowed into Mandarin as é»‘å®¢ (hÄ“ikÃ¨, "wicked visitor" (black guest))  
å£°çº³ shÄ“ngnÃ  "sonar", which uses the characters å£° shÄ“ng "sound" and çº³ nÃ  "nehme, receive, accept"  

Chinese has a large number of homo/heterotonal homophonous morphemes, which would have been much better phonetic fit in sonar, but not nearly as good semantically: song (cf. é€ sÃ²ng â€˜deliver, carry, give (as a present)â€™, æ¾ sÅng â€˜pine; loose, slackâ€™, è€¸ sÇ’ng â€˜tower; alarm, attractâ€™ etc.), sou (cf. æœ sÅu â€˜searchâ€™, åŸ sÅu â€˜old manâ€™, é¦Š sÅu â€˜sour, spoiledâ€™ and many others) or shou (cf. æ”¶ shÅu â€˜receive, acceptâ€™, å— shÃ²u â€˜receive, acceptâ€™, æ‰‹ shÇ’u â€˜handâ€™, é¦– shÇ’u â€˜headâ€™, å…½ shÃ²u â€˜beastâ€™, ç˜¦ shÃ²u â€˜thinâ€™ and so forth)."[9]  
æœçº³ sÅunÃ  and è€¸çº³ shounÃ  would be ok!

åˆç¾½ (kappa) for the Portuguese capa, a kind of raincoat. The characters can mean "wings coming together", as the pointed capa resembles a bird with wings folded together.

# forced associations
in times when syllabic signs and the letters of the alphabet where not abstract but defined through their ( [rebus](rebus.html) ) root, naturally all words using those signs became strongly associated. This was sometimes alleviated through [complement](complement.html) orthograpyh.  

# desired ambivalence

One strong feature of symbolic and even spoken languages per se is that parts can be associated in myriad ways, children do this conciously and unconciously and have to unlearn those associations which are not supported by their environment.  

Poets can often make use of such associations and in the beginnings the **rebus** principle was even the biggest enabler of written language. Puns were often indistinguishable from expressive necessity.  

ğ“  ğ“ˆ– ğ“ƒ’ ğ“€¸  â²™â²â²›â²‰â²¥â²±â²Ÿâ²© manager ğ’Œ‹ğ’Œ‹ğ’Œ†ğ’‡»  man-tu-ru mentor maintainer â€œchief herdsmanâ€

# inverse rebus principle
_ğ’‰ºğ’‹¢ 	pas'pa-su | duck | Ø¨Øª bat ( ğ“…­  


# acronym readings &
# subunit matching

Acronym readings are an extreme form of PSM and can yield almost anything, any connection in any language.  
This is why in the analysis of words in the dictionary corpus, splitting long sequences of signs into short meaning-lets instantly yields absurd connections at the scholars volition. Most of them likely wrong. Under all circumstances must a most exhaustive matching be preferred to a subunit matching. Prime example being  

ğ“…“ ğ“‚ ğ“ƒ­ ğ“¤ ğ“¡ ğ“„¿ ğ“ƒ€ ğ“² ğ“˜ ğ“‡‹ ğ“†± [ğ“Œ](ğ“Œ.html) horse chariot  
Even though splitting the word into components (lion-hunter / horse-car) might be completly reasonable,  
the best etymology is no etymology at all:  
ğ“…“ ğ“‚ ğ“ƒ­ ğ“¤ ğ“¡ ğ“„¿ ğ“ƒ€ ğ“² ğ“˜ ğ“‡‹ ğ“†± | horse chariot | ğğ—ğ‹ğğš mrkbt /markabtu/  

On the other hand [alphabetic-change](alphabetic-change.html) can broaden the possibile associations even further.  
This quickly results in the [wildcard-fallacy](wildcard-fallacy.html)  
ğ“› ğ“‡³ ğ“› | forever eternal | âˆš[DURA](DURA.html)  

# reinterpretation of names
PSM reinterpretation of corrupted [name](name.html)s is ubiquitous [Bad-Linguistics](Bad-Linguistics.html)

Icelandic  DANGER: PIE!  

eyÃ°ni, meaning "AIDS", is a PSM of the English acronym AIDS, using the pre-existent Icelandic verb eyÃ°a, meaning "to destroy"  

tÃ¦kni, meaning "technology, technique", derives from tÃ¦ki, meaning "tool", combined with the nominal suffix -ni, but is, in fact, a PSM of the Danish (or international) teknik, meaning "technology, technique"    TRUE neo-COGNATE! (re-) =>  

tÃ¦knilegur "technical" and tÃ¦knir "technician"  

okul Ã©cole 'school' lat: schola (cf. the original Turkish coinage okula(ÄŸ) â‡” oculus: eye  
co-etymon of okul is Turkish oku- '(to) read', cf. okumak 'to read, study', okuma 'reading', okur 'reader'. Note the semantic affinity with Arabic ÙƒØªØ¨ kataba 'wrote (masculine, singular)', the ultimate origin of Ottoman Turkish mektep.  

synchronically, Turkish okul cannot be regarded as Ã¶ztÃ¼rkÃ§e (pure Turkish) since the final -l is not a Turkish suffix and was imported ad hoc from French.  

Ã¶z = purez erz!  

I used to live with an Irish gal named Mhairi...everyone thought (from Facebook etc) her name was essentially 'Mary', but it was in fact, pronounced 'Very'.

# capital Memphis PSM
The Greek forms of Egypt (Î‘á¼´Î³Ï…Ï€Ï„Î¿Ï‚) were borrowed from Late Egyptian (Amarna) Hikuptah or "Memphis", a corruption of the earlier Egyptian name âŸ¨á¸¥wt-kÈ-ptá¸¥âŸ© ğ“‰—ğ“ğ“‰ğ“‚“ğ“¤ğ“Šªğ“ğ“› meaning "Home of the ka (ghost) of Ptah", the name of a temple to the god Ptah at Memphis.

# nectar
ğ“ˆ– ğ“†“ ğ“‡› ğ“…“ â²›â²Ÿâ²©â²§â²‰â²™ <> nectar Î½Îµ- or Î½Î·- "not" plus ÎºÏ„Î±- or ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ½- "kill", meaning "unkillable", thus "immortal"
